-    - type: [ISSUE, ASSIGNEE]:

body: "Comment" implication isn't clear to me

I've always been anti empty string for variable declarations. It's led to too many problems with other less experienced developers. I wish for a linter rule to flag these as a consequence. 

Consider initializing an empty array as a buffer and then joining it at the end.
Our RPCs don't work anymore

I think in this case it makes sense because this function will return `""` if nothing is found. If I return `undefined` or `null` it will be interpreted in HTML as a string and will display the text null or undefined.

I changed the code to always return `content` so it forces it to be properly initialized which should avoid mistakes.

body:
Perhaps it will make the config more expressive if you add other properties?

For example 

```yml

observe:
   views:
      - ISSUE
      - PULL
   actors:
      - ISSUER 
      - COLLABORATOR 
   actions: 
      - COMMENTED

```

Just noticed the bit wise operators 1337 code

It might seem convoluted but I think that it condenses the logic to coerce everything into a string as expected. This is a suggestion to be proactive when we set up the empty string linter one day.

[ null, null ].join(""); // ""

null += null; // 0 I think?

body: Shouldn't task be issue opening item and specification is pull request opening item? At least that's how I understand from the code.
I assume this is a permit for task assignee, but where are other permits or is that not done yet?

By definition `dump` was just outputting results to stdout, but I could make it return the result as well. Since the console log is what we want to make sure works properly to be reused by other workflows, I thought it would make sense to test it that way because potentially if we forget other logs somewhere that would mess up the output for the next Action step.
Un-nested them one level. I think that the `buildXrow` should just be contained by that function because its purpose only serves inside of it.
I assumed BigInt only handles integers, and we manipulate a lot of floating decimal values for our operations (mostly everything has a floating point)

There is one permit generated per participating user, last run:
https://github.com/Meniole/test/issues/1#issuecomment-2069443938

Why not do it in the industry standard way? All values are denominated in `1e18` without floating point. 

At the end, for rendering, we just need to divide by `1e18`

I made it according to the previous version:
- Issue Specification means the item when opening an issue
- Issue Task means the item that fixed the issue

Example with the current comments:
https://github.com/ubiquibot/comment-incentives/issues/31#issuecomment-1998609326
Wouldn't that lead to precision loss in JS and after the division we could end up with 42.000000001 results? That's also what `DecimalJs` fixes in this case.

body:
That is correct. I understand now why you're confused:

The value for the task would be
`"ISSUE|ISSUER|TASK"`
because it is inside the `issue`

The value for the Specification would be
`"REVIEW|ISSUER|SPECIFICATION"`
because it is inside the `pull`

I display `Issue: Specification` and `Issue: Task` just to stick to our current display format. Maybe instead I could display `Review: Task` instead?

body:
Spoke a bit on this in dms. @whilefoo my intent with referring to GitHub Issues as "tasks" was to emphasize that its a funded, and recognized "real project" so I want to refer to them as "tasks" instead of just "issues."

Since we are dealing so heavily with the GitHub API, I figured that there is benefit to being specific about what words we are using. Sure we can load in all the GitHub issues on a repository, but not all of them will be funded and recognized. 

We are only primarily concerned with working with "tasks" aka funded GitHub issues.
Possibly. I personally haven't had that issue but either way my suggestion is to keep everything internally without a decimal and then only convert it upon rendering.

I don't think is it relevant in this scenario because we are not manipulating big numbers. Decimaljs allows for non-precision loss on the operations because there is a lot of multiply / divide with floating points which can result in very long decimals due to Js nature.
Ok so we need it for precise floating point calculations, in that case BigInt is not applicable.

body:
@whilefoo you are correct, these were wrongly used. I corrected `TASK` and replaced it by `SPECIFICATION` so we have:
`"ISSUE|ISSUER|SPECIFICATION"` and `"REVIEW|ISSUER|TASK"`

I used `ISSUER` for this because technically the issuer is not necessarily the assignee in both cases.

Fix within next PR:
https://github.com/ubiquibot/conversation-rewards/pull/14/commits/90e150f76073c9cfa16a251f8c1ae48a75aa5408
